heroes.name: Jocko Willink
heroes.coreThesis: Jocko Willink teaches that leadership is about Extreme Ownership—taking full responsibility for everything in your world, no excuses. Discipline doesn't restrict freedom; it creates it. The more disciplined your routines, preparation, and standards, the more freedom you have to act decisively when it matters. Default aggressive: when uncertain, move forward with initiative. "Good": when setbacks happen, immediately reframe them as opportunities. Decentralized Command: empower your team to make decisions by clearly communicating the mission's "why." Prioritize and Execute: when overwhelmed, detach emotionally, identify the highest-priority problem, solve it, then move to the next. It's not what you preach; it's what you tolerate.
operatingPrinciples: Extreme Ownership: as the leader, everything is your fault. No blame, no excuses.
Discipline equals freedom. Rigid routines create capacity for decisive action.
Default aggressive. Bias toward initiative and forward movement.
"Good." Respond to every setback by finding the opportunity in it.
Prioritize and execute. Step back, identify the most critical issue, tackle it first.
Decentralized Command. Empower your team to make decisions; trust them.
Simple plans win. If the newest person can't understand it, simplify.
Check the ego. Humility enables learning; ego prevents it.
Detach. Step outside emotions to see the situation objectively.
Lead up and down. Manage your boss as much as you lead your team.
It's not what you preach, it's what you tolerate. Enforced standards become real standards.
Cover and Move. Teams must support each other; mission first, egos second.

decisionFilters.description: Am I emotionally hijacked? If yes, step back and reassess.

decisionFilters.description: What single problem, if solved, would have the biggest impact?

failureModes: Blaming others - Pointing fingers instead of taking ownership
Micromanaging - Not trusting decentralized command, controlling every detail
Overcomplicating - Plans too complex for execution under pressure
Ego-driven decisions - Prioritizing personal image over mission success
Hesitation - Waiting for perfect information instead of defaulting aggressive
signatureTactics: 4:30 AM wake-up - Discipline starts with morning routine
Physical training daily - Builds discipline that transfers to leadership
"Good" response to setbacks - Immediate reframe to prevent emotional spiral
After Action Reviews (AAR) - Debrief every mission/project to extract lessons
Detachment practice - Mentally step outside situations to assess objectively
Leading up - Give your boss what they need before they ask
Simple brief-backs - Test team understanding by having them explain the plan back
heroes.oneLiner: Own everything, execute with discipline, default aggressive on priorities, and respond to every setback with "Good"—now get after it.

heroes.name: Naval Ravikant
heroes.coreThesis: Naval Ravikant teaches that wealth and happiness are both learnable skills, not luck. Build wealth through specific knowledge (what only you can do), leverage (capital/code/media that multiply effort), and accountability (take risks under your own name). Escape the time-for-money trap by owning equity, not renting your time. Play long-term games with long-term people—all returns come from compound interest. For happiness, recognize that desire is self-imposed suffering. Reduce desires, practice presence, meditate by doing nothing. The three big things are wealth, health, and happiness. We chase them in that order, but their importance is reversed. Read voraciously, think clearly, act decisively. Learn to sell, learn to build. If you can do both, you're unstoppable.
operatingPrinciples: Wealth is assets that earn while you sleep. Own equity, don't rent your time.
Specific knowledge + Leverage + Accountability = wealth formula.
Play long-term games with long-term people. Compound interest dominates.
Wealth creation is positive-sum. Status is zero-sum. Choose wealth, ignore status.
Happiness is a learnable skill. Reduce desires, practice presence, accept reality.
Desire is a contract to be unhappy until you get what you want. Focus on one desire at a time.
Reading compounds knowledge. Read 1-2 hours daily. Read what you love until you love to read.
Clear thinking → better judgment → better outcomes. Optimize for clarity.
Meditation is doing nothing. Sit, close eyes, let happen what happens.
Learn to sell, learn to build. Combination makes you unstoppable.
True rewards come from ignoring others and improving yourself.
Inputs (effort) are controllable. Outputs (results) aren't. Optimize inputs, detach from outputs.

One-desire focus - Identify single most important goal, let all other desires dissolve
heroes.oneLiner: Build wealth through specific knowledge, leverage, and accountability—but remember, the real game is reducing desires to find peace.

heroes.name: Eliud Kipchoge
heroes.coreThesis: Eliud Kipchoge teaches that no human is limited—limits exist in the mind, not the body. The greatest marathoner in history lives in a simple Kenyan training camp, makes chapatis for teammates, and hasn't questioned his coach in 18 years. Discipline equals freedom: structure liberates mental energy for performance. Athletics is about the heart and mind, not just the legs. Success comes from planning well, preparing well, and trusting the process without constant second-guessing. Run 80% easy, 20% hard—patience compounds over decades. Respect pain; it makes the mind strong. When setbacks happen (Paris DNF at age 39), treat them as challenges, not endings. Simplicity enables excellence. Humility despite greatness. Self-belief precedes possibility. Do your best—there's nothing else.
operatingPrinciples: No human is limited. Mental limits are self-imposed; question every "I can't."
Only the disciplined ones are free. Without discipline, you're a slave to moods and passions.
Athletics is about the heart and mind, not just the legs. Mental training precedes physical output.
Simplicity enables excellence. Cut complexity, focus on fundamentals, avoid distractions.
Trust the process without questioning. Kipchoge hasn't asked "why" in 18 years. If you trust the system, execute.
Plan meticulously, prepare thoroughly. Success comes when you plan well and prepare well.
80% easy, 20% hard. Slow runs build fast races. Consistency beats intensity over time.
Respect pain; it builds mental strength. "Long runs make my mind strong, consistent, and respect that pain."
Self-belief is crucial. Belief must precede possibility. "Any human can go beyond their thoughts."
Humility despite excellence. World's best marathoner still does camp chores, makes chapatis for teammates.
Setbacks are challenges, not endings. Paris DNF: "I treat it as a challenge. Accept what happened and move on."
Do your best. There's nothing else. (Patrick Sang's teaching, Kipchoge's credo.)

Impatience - Overtraining, seeking intensity over consistency, wanting results now

signatureTactics: Simple training camp - Minimalist environment in Kaptagat, Kenya, no distractions, shared chores

Challenge reframing - Paris DNF treated as setback to learn from, not career-ending failure
heroes.oneLiner: No human is limited—the barrier is in your mind. Only the disciplined are free. Do your best. There's nothing else.

heroes.name: Andrew Huberman
heroes.coreThesis: Andrew Huberman teaches that the nervous system is your operating system, and you have far more control over it than you think. Through neuroplasticity, you can rewire circuits for focus, stress resilience, motivation, and performance. The key is understanding mechanisms (why protocols work) and implementing zero-cost, science-based tools: morning sunlight for circadian alignment, NSDR for dopamine restoration, cold exposure for resilience, physiological sighs for immediate calm. Behavior change isn't mystery—it's applied neuroscience. The only things you truly control are attention and effort. Choose wisely, act deliberately, and leverage your nervous system's adaptability.
operatingPrinciples: Neuroplasticity is real: every action rewires your brain. Direct this deliberately.
Morning sunlight (2-10 min, 30-60 min after waking) sets circadian biology. Non-negotiable foundation.
NSDR (yoga nidra, hypnosis) restores dopamine, compensates for bad sleep, aids learning consolidation.
Deliberate cold exposure builds stress resilience by training calm during sympathetic activation.
Dopamine releases during pursuit, not just achievement. Celebrate small wins to sustain motivation.
Physiological sigh (double inhale, long exhale) is fastest real-time stress reduction tool.
Visual focus (narrow gaze) triggers cognitive focus. Use before deep work.
Gratitude resets dopamine via serotonin. High performers use this to sustain effort.
Stress is tool when paired with recovery. Chronic stress without rest = burnout.
Understand mechanisms. Knowing why protocols work builds confidence and prevents cargo-cult behavior.
The nervous system loves predictability. Consistent routines reduce baseline anxiety.
Attention and effort are the only things you truly control. Allocate them wisely.

decisionFilters.name: The Circadian Check
decisionFilters.description: Does this align with my biology? (Light exposure, sleep timing, meal timing.)

decisionFilters.name: The Mechanism Question
decisionFilters.description: What's the peer-reviewed research? Can I explain why this works neurobiologically?

decisionFilters.name: The Dopamine Delta
decisionFilters.description: Will this deplete or restore my motivation baseline? Avoid cheap hits; seek earned rewards.

decisionFilters.name: The Stress-Rest Ratio
decisionFilters.description: Do I have matching recovery protocol for this stressor? No rest = no adaptation.

decisionFilters.name: The Attention Audit
decisionFilters.description: Where am I placing attention right now? Does it serve my goals?

failureModes: Protocol without mechanism - Following advice blindly without understanding why it works
Circadian disruption - Ignoring morning sunlight, inconsistent sleep, artificial light at night
Dopamine depletion - Chasing cheap rewards (social media, constant novelty) that crash baseline
Chronic stress without recovery - Grinding without NSDR, gratitude, or rest protocols
Passivity - Letting nervous system run on autopilot instead of taking deliberate control
signatureTactics: Morning sunlight exposure - 2-10 minutes outside within 30-60 min of waking, sets circadian clock
NSDR (Non-Sleep Deep Rest) - 10-20 min yoga nidra or hypnosis daily, restores dopamine
Deliberate cold exposure - 1-3 min cold plunge/shower, 2-3x per week, builds resilience
Physiological sigh - Double inhale through nose, extended exhale through mouth, calms in real-time
Visual focus training - Narrow gaze before deep work to trigger cognitive focus
Gratitude practice - Acknowledge small wins to reset dopamine baseline
Mechanism-first learning - Always ask "why does this work?" before implementing
heroes.oneLiner: Your nervous system is trainable—get morning sunlight to set your clock, use NSDR to restore dopamine, and remember that attention and effort are the only things you truly control.

heroes.name: Seneca (the Younger)
heroes.coreThesis: Seneca teaches that life is not short—we waste it. Most of death is already gone; whatever time has passed is owned by death. Guard your time more carefully than your property. Fortune is fickle: never trust her favors (wealth, power, reputation); she can reclaim them instantly. The only true good is virtue. Death is not the end—it's continuous, already happening. Confront mortality daily to clarify priorities. Destructive passions (especially anger) must be mastered through reason. The whole future is uncertain—live immediately. Putting things off is the biggest waste of life. Practice voluntary discomfort to prepare for fortune's reversals. Philosophy is not a badge of superiority; it's a tool for self-improvement. Seneca never claimed to be a Stoic sage, just someone working toward virtue, often failing, always trying.
operatingPrinciples: Time is your only non-renewable resource. Guard it more carefully than money.
Life is long if you know how to use it. Most squander it on trivia.
Most of death is already gone. Whatever time has passed is owned by death.
The whole future is uncertain. Live immediately. Don't postpone life.
Fortune is fickle. Never trust her gifts (wealth, power, reputation). She can reclaim them instantly.
Virtue is the only true good. External goods are preferred indifferents, not intrinsically good.
Confront mortality daily (memento mori). It clarifies priorities and removes death's terror.
Master destructive passions (anger, grief, fear) through reason. Anger is temporary madness.
Practice voluntary discomfort to prepare for fortune's reversals and prevent luxury dependence.
Philosophy is practice, not theory. Life without learning is death; learning without living is equally dead.
Control your responses, not events. You control judgments and values; Fortune controls outcomes.
Simplicity despite abundance. Whether rich or poor, cultivate inner detachment from externals.

decisionFilters.name: The Time Valuation Test

decisionFilters.name: The Fortune Reversal Exercise

decisionFilters.name: The Simplicity Check

failureModes: Time waste - Squandering life on trivia, postponing living until "someday"
Fortune-worship - Trusting external goods (wealth, power, reputation) as if they're permanent
Death avoidance - Refusing to confront mortality, living as if immortal
Anger indulgence - Letting external events trigger temporary madness, harming self and others
Luxury dependence - Becoming enslaved to comfort, losing resilience to fortune's reversals
signatureTactics: Daily memento mori meditation - "Whatever can happen at any time can happen today. If I died tonight..."
Time audit - Regularly ask: "Am I trading life for this? Is this worth it?"
Voluntary poverty practice - Set aside days/weeks for simple living: basic food, rough clothes, hard surfaces
Fortune reversal visualization - Before accepting external goods, imagine losing them tomorrow
Anger pause protocol - When feeling anger rise, pause before acting. Create space for reason.
Morning reflection - Review how you'll use today (not waste it), what matters (given mortality)
Philosophical journaling - Write to yourself (like Letters to Lucilius) tracking progress toward virtue
heroes.oneLiner: Life is not short—you waste it. Most of death is already gone. Guard your time, distrust Fortune's favors, and remember: whatever can happen at any time can happen today.

heroes.name: Marcus Aurelius
heroes.coreThesis: Marcus Aurelius teaches that true power lies in mastering your mind, not controlling external events. The universe operates by rational order; suffering comes from resisting this order through false judgments about what's "good" or "bad." The only genuine good is virtue (wisdom, justice, courage, temperance); everything else—health, wealth, reputation, even life itself—is "indifferent." Obstacles aren't problems; they're opportunities for practicing virtue. Death is natural and imminent; this fact should focus your attention on living excellently now, not later. You have a duty to contribute to human community while maintaining inner tranquility.
operatingPrinciples: Distinguish what you control (thoughts, judgments, responses) from what you don't (everything else). Invest energy only in your control.
Transform obstacles into opportunities. Every impediment is raw material for virtue.
Practice memento mori: remember you will die. This clarifies what matters.
Cultivate virtuous thoughts; your habitual thinking shapes your character.
Treat all humans as rational family members. Even those who harm act from ignorance.
The present moment is all you possess. Live it excellently.
Rehearse adversity before it arrives. Mental preparation prevents emotional hijacking.
Simplify. Luxury creates dependency; simplicity creates freedom.
Do your duty to community while maintaining inner independence.
Act with virtue, release attachment to outcomes.
Your mind is an impregnable fortress if you maintain it.
Don't complain about what nature provides. Acceptance reduces suffering.

decisionFilters.name: The Virtue Filter
decisionFilters.description: Does this align with wisdom, justice, courage, or temperance? If not, reject.

decisionFilters.name: The Nature Alignment

heroes.oneLiner: Control what you can (your mind), accept what you can't (everything else), and remember—you'll be dead soon, so waste no time on trivialities.

quotes.text: The impediment to action advances action. What stands in the way becomes the way.
Such as are thy habitual thoughts, such also will be the character of thy mind; for the soul is dyed by the thoughts.

heroes.name: David Goggins
heroes.coreThesis: David Goggins teaches that most humans operate at 40% of their true capability and never discover what they're made of. The mind quits to protect you from discomfort—not danger. When you think you're done, you're only 40% done; there's 60% more in reserve. Growth only happens through suffering. Comfort is the enemy of potential. The Accountability Mirror (facing brutal truth about yourself), the Cookie Jar (banking past wins to draw on), and callusing your mind through repeated voluntary suffering are how you become unbreakable. Motivation is garbage; drive is everything. There is no finish line—you're either growing or dying.
operatingPrinciples: When your mind says quit, you're only 40% done. Push through to access the other 60%.
Callous your mind through repeated voluntary suffering (cold, hard workouts, discomfort).
The Accountability Mirror: write failures and goals on Post-its, tag your mirror, face truth daily.
The Cookie Jar: mentally bank every hard thing you've overcome. Pull from it when you want to quit.
Motivation is trash. Driven people execute regardless of feelings.
Take souls: outwork everyone so dominantly they feel demoralized by your output.
Comfort is the enemy. If it's easy, you're not growing.
Own your past. Use trauma/failure as fuel, not excuse.
There is no finish line. You're either growing or declining—choose growth.
Stay hard. Not a phrase, a permanent operating state.
Do the thing you're avoiding. Your weaknesses define your ceiling.
Early mornings separate committed from casual. 4AM is the standard.

decisionFilters.name: The Comfort Test

decisionFilters.name: The 4AM Question

decisionFilters.name: The Suffering Filter

failureModes: Making excuses - Any justification for not doing the work
Seeking comfort - Taking easy path, avoiding discomfort
Waiting for motivation - Needing to "feel like it" before acting
Playing victim - Using past trauma as excuse for current failure
Quitting when it's hard - Listening to the 40% quit signal instead of pushing to 100%
signatureTactics: 4AM wake-ups - Dominate the morning before others are awake
Accountability Mirror - Post-it notes with failures/goals on bathroom mirror
Cookie Jar - Mental inventory of past hard wins to draw on when struggling
Callusing routine - Repeated exposure to cold, fatigue, discomfort
Ultra-endurance training - Long suffering sessions to build mental armor
Taking souls - Outwork everyone to demoralize competition
No days off mentality - Every day is a training day
heroes.oneLiner: You're operating at 40%—stop making excuses, face the mirror, pull from your cookie jar, and stay hard.

quotes.text: You are in danger of living a life so comfortable that you will die without ever realizing your true potential.
The most important conversations you'll ever have are the ones you'll have with yourself.
Motivation changes exactly nobody.
Don't focus on what you think you deserve. Take aim on what you are willing to earn!
We live in a world where a lot of people need goals and want to pursue them, but don't want to pay the price to achieve them.

It won't always go your way, so you can't get trapped in this idea that just because you imagined a possibility for yourself that you somehow deserve it.
The only way that you're going to get to the other side of this journey is by suffering. You have to suffer in order to grow.
We all have the ability to come from nothing to something.
